title: Business News: Nike's Sales, Net Income Decline As Stores Report Excess Inventory
text:
Matthew Friend, Nike's finance chief, said the company was monitoring consumer behavior and the impact of high inflation on demand. He said Nike would take a cautious approach in China given uncertainty around additional Covid disruptions.

He also said the company would be raising prices on some items by a mid-single digit percentage.

"We will stay focused on what we can control," Mr. Friend said on a conference call.

For the quarter ended May 31, total sales decreased 1% to $12.2 billion. Net income fell 5% to $1.44 billion, or 90 cents a share. The fiscal fourth-quarter results were better than Wall Street analysts had predicted.

Revenue in the North American market, which accounts for the majority of total sales, declined 5% to $5.1 billion. Sales in China declined 19% to $1.56 billion, mostly because of Covid-19 restrictions in the country.

Sales jumped in Europe, the Middle East and parts of Asia, compared with a year ago.

Some retailers have reported having excess inventory and having to sell products at a discount.

Supply-chain disruptions are still having an impact on Nike's flow of goods, Mr. Friend said.

The company is paying about five times the prepandemic rate it paid to put its products in a container and move them from Asia to the U.S. Transit times remain elevated and aren't expected to significantly improve during the coming fiscal year.

The company reported a 23% increase in inventory in the May quarter compared with the prior year.
